description: Foundational approaches to media as a means of defining and distributing social power in everyday life.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Global Media Industries
description: Provides the foundation for the study of globalized film and media industries.   FS: 11/1/2017.

name: Special Topics In Popular Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in popular film and media. May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Classical Hollywood Cinema
description: Survey of Classical Hollywood Cinema in aesthetic, cultural, political, and economic contexts.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Music and the Hollywood Film
description: Examination of how music guides audience interpretation and shapes Hollywood film style.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Superheroes across Media
description: Examination of the superhero within and across media, industries, and eras addressing topics such as genre, style, seriality, remediation, franchising, and fandom.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: The Blockbuster
description: Examination of the post-1975 blockbuster film phenomenon with an emphasis on marketing, finance, and reception.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Non-Film Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning a medium or mediums other than film.  May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: American Television
description: Examination of American television as an industry, art form, medium of social representation, and set of viewer practices.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Contemporary British Television Industry
description: Examination of industrial structures, network histories, production cultures, and regulation contexts of contemporary British television.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Comics Studies
description: Scholarly study of the formal and aesthetic evolutions of graphic novels, comic books, and other related forms.     FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Global Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media centered outside the U.S. May be repeated up to three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Middle East on Screen
description: Examines representations of the Middle East on screen within multiple media-making traditions and considers their aesthetic, political, and ethical dimensions.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Hong Kong Action Cinema
description: Survey of the transnational history of Hong Kong action cinema and introduction to critical approaches through which it has been studied.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Screening China
description: Survey of Chinese language cinema. Chinese film history and vocabulary with which to discuss film texts. Covers classic leftwing cinema, Hong Kong martial arts films, as well as the Hong Kong, Taiwan, and PRC New Waves. Taught in English. Films subtitled.    FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Alternative Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning film and media forms and/or practices outside the commercial mainstream. May be repeated as many as three times for a total of nine credit hours as content varies by title.   FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: History of Experimental Film
description: Survey of key examples and tendencies in the history of experimental film.    FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Documentary Studies
description: History, theory, and practices of documentary film and media.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and program director is required.   FS: 12/2/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Genre Studies Film & Media
description: Critical study of a popular genre (e.g., horror, science fiction, melodrama), or set of genres, in film and media. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of courses by title.  May be repeated as topics vary.   FS: 12/2/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Internship in Film and Media Studies
description: Internship in Film and Media Studies. (Variable) Supervised professional experience working with media production, distribution, exhibition, archiving, and/or education.    FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Film and Media Histories
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media history. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 06/02/2021.

name: Special Topics in Film and Media Studies
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 12/02/2015.

name: Special Topics in U.S. Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic in U.S. film and media studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 09/10/2014.

name: Critical Interactives
description: Foundational techniques in multidisciplinary software development, specifically of applications designed to present sensitive, sometimes controversial, materials in ways to engender empathic awareness of the interactor.     FS: 11/01/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Global Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning films produced in a country other than the United States. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Personal Finance
description: Course will provide a basic framework for student personal financial management while in college. Topics include money management skills, banking, credit cards, creditworthiness, credit reports, students loans, identity theft, and basic taxes.   FS: 12/07/2022.

name: Money and Banking
description: The role of money in the market economy. Commercial banks, the Federal Reserve System, and monetary policy.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Finance and Markets
description: In-depth introduction to the world of finance.  Interaction of individuals and companies with financial markets.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Management of Risk and Insurance
description: Introduction to decision making under uncertainty and overview of how carious markets allow individuals and organizations to diversify risk. Includes measurement of risk, behavioral bias in decision making under uncertainty, diversification of risk, the role of capital in ensuring performance, moral hazard, adverse selection, insurance pricing, and applications to public policy issues such as health care, catastrophe risk, and safety regulation.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Finance
description: Basic concepts of finance related to decision making.   FS: 09/14/2022.

name: Financial Institutions
description: A study of the functions and operations of financial institutions and their relationships to the commercial banking system and the general economy. Attention is devoted to savings institutions, insurance companies, rural and urban real estate credit, consumer credit, and associated topics.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Corporate Financial Analysis
description: Analysis of business investment and financing decisions.   FS: 04/06/2022.

name: Introduction to Real Estate and Urban Development
description: Real estate analysis and administration; basic principles, concepts, terminology, and institutional factors related to real estate decisions in the urban environment. This course fulfills a pre-examination requirement of the South Carolina Real Estate licensing law (30-hour approved course).   FS: 06/07/2023.

name: Real Estate Market Analysis
description: Concepts, methodologies, and analytical tools used in urban real estate analysis.   CL: 2020.

name: Personal Finance
description: Life insurance, health insurance, wills, trusts, Social Security, stocks, bonds, real estate, mutual funds, and other uses of funds.   FS: 04/06/2022.

name: Life and Health Insurance
description: Individual financial management of economic losses caused by premature death, disability, and old age; functional aspects of life-health insurer management.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Property and Liability Insurance
description: Functional aspects of property-liability insurer management and operations including detailed treatment of pricing, risk assessment, marketing, investment, contract design, financial statement analysis, and regulation.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Corporate Risk Management
description: Tools and concepts used by corporations in managing all types of risk with a focus on the use of derivatives and insurance. Analysis of when risk reduction is beneficial.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Employee Benefits
description: Management of employer-sponsored benefits, especially group life, health, and retirement plans; emphasis on plan design and administration, cost, funding, regulation, and tax considerations.   CL: 2020.

name: Insurance Operations
description: Innovative insurance operations to compete in the modern world.    FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Case Studies in Corporate Finance
description: Application of financial concepts and tools to corporate decisions.   FS: 02/07/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Financial Innovation
description: Explores the history, current environment, and near term outlook of financial innovation (FinTech), focusing on applications of Blockchain technology and Machine Learning tools. The course is designed to provide hands on experience in writing a €smart contract€? using a blockchain and in applying machine learning tools.   FS: 02/03/2021.

name: Commercial Bank Practice and Policy
description: Fundamental principles underlying the employment of bank funds. Allocation of funds among the various classes of loans and investments to bank operating costs and to changing bank practices.   FS: 04/04/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Real Estate Investment Fundamentals
description: Analysis and decision-making; return and risk; financing; tax implications; pricing and investment strategies.   CL: 2020.

name: Real Estate Finance
description: The nature and importance of credit in real estate development and operations; legal framework, sources of mortgage funds, role of public and private financial institutions.   CL: 2020.

name: Real Estate Appraisal
description: Traditional appraisal concepts and methodologies; appraisal process, real property analysis.   CL: 2020.

name: Investment Analysis and Portfolio Management
description: Conceptual and analytical framework for formulating investment policies, analyzing securities, and constructing portfolios.   FS: 04/06/2022.

name: Financial Statement Analysis
description: This course focuses on the analysis of financial statements for profitability and risk assessment and for firm and segment valuation.   CL: 2020.

name: Derivative Securities
description: Options, forward and futures contracts, and swap contracts are analyzed, along with their uses in risk management, portfolio management, and corporate financing. Markets where these contracts trade will be examined.   FS: 02/07/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Student-Managed Investments
description: Hands-on experience in investment analysis; managing a real portfolio, decision-making in the design of a portfolio management process, asset allocation, security selection, and risk management.   Enrollment in this course requires a special permission from the instructor.   FS: 06/01/2022.

name: Corporate Governance and Agency Conflicts
description: Exploring conflicts of interest between corporate managers and the providers of capital, and studying various mechanisms to address the misalignment of incentives and therefore restore firm value.   FS: 12/02/2020.

name: Fixed Income Securities
description: Examine fundamental principles of fixed-income securities and fixed-income valuation models.   CL: 2020.

name: Foundations of Capitalism
description: Examines the foundations of capitalism and why it has prevailed over alternative systems. Topics include the justification of private property, distribution of wealth, profit motive, source of wealth creation, and others.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Real Estate Development
description: Introduction to the real estate development process with emphasis on analyzing the feasibility of design, location, and construction. Students will learn to identify and evaluate critical issues related to market and site feasibility, financial feasibility, planning, acquisition, and operation of viable real estate projects.   FS: 06/07/2023.

name: Global Real Estate Capital Markets
description: Global institutional investment in real estate;  international capital markets viewed from the perspective of real estate investment and finance professionals.   FS: 11/1/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Finance
description: 1-3 credit hours for up to 9 credit hours total.   FS: 06/03/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Business Internship in Finance, Real Estate and Insurance
description: Supervised work experience as approved by department. Generally three hours of academic credit, but upon special request of supervising professor and approval of appropriate area director, an internship may carry a maximum of six credit hours. Pass-Fail only. Internship contract required.   FS: 09/08/2021.

name: Risk Management
description: Covers the concepts and tools businesses use when managing risk. Adopts an enterprise risk management perspective, i.e., considers a variety of risk exposures and methods for managing these risks. Main objective is to provide a decision-making framework applicable to different risk situations.    GC: 05/11/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Investment Management
description: The use of analytical techniques to evaluate investment opportunities with consideration given to applicable quantitative methods of portfolio management.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Intercultural Communication
description: This course offers an introduction to intercultural communication while addressing areas such as cultural self-awareness and competence, intercultural interactions, and the roles of context and power in intercultural communication. Students will reflect on the importance of intercultural communication to better recognize and appreciate others€ unique qualities during travel, business, study abroad, work and daily life.   FS: 10/05/2022.

name: Selected Topics
description: Studies in language not otherwise taught. May include a cultural and/or linguistic component.

name: Teaching Internship in Foreign Languages
description: Application of effective teaching techniques and organization of instructional settings in foreign languages for K-12.

name: Introduction to Technology in Language Education
description: Acquaints students with principles and practices concerning the use of technology in foreign language teaching. Explores connections between second language acquisition and the implementation of Internet and multimedia technologies.   FS: 11/7/2018.

name: Directed Teaching in Foreign Languages
description: Students apply methods of curriculum and assessment, professionalism, effective teaching, and organization of instructional settings during internship in foreign language classroom.   FS: 02/05/2020.

name: Spanish for Medical Personnel
description: Basic course in health professions. Functional language and lexicon as well as cultural practices for interaction with Hispanic clients.   CL: 2020.

name: Teaching Second Languages to Young Children
description: To assist prospective teachers of young children in the development of a second language and multicultural learning activities. Practicum sessions are an integral part.   CL: 2020.

name: Teaching Foreign Languages in Secondary Schools
description: Current methods, techniques, and materials of instruction appropriate for secondary schools.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Global Film and Media
description: Intensive study of a specific topic concerning films produced in a country other than the United States. May be repeated as content varies by title.    FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Beginning French I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.  Admission to FREN 109 restricted to those who have never studied French, who have not studied French in the previous five years, or who have a score of F-1 on the placement test.   CL: 2020.

name: Beginning French II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.  Admission to 110 restricted to those who have completed FREN 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following: FREN 109/FREN 110 or FREN 121.   CL: 2020.

name: Elementary French
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.  Assumes prior experience in French. Admission to FREN 121 restricted to those who have a score of F-2 on the placement test. Credit may be received for only one of the following: FREN 109/FREN 100 or FREN 121.   FS: 03/07/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Basic Proficiency in French
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.    FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Reading and Written Expression
description: Readings in French; grammar, basic writing, and composition.   CL: 2020.

name: Oral Communication
description: Practice in conversation involving authentic listening materials; vocabulary building.   CL: 2020.

name: French Literature in Translation
description: Readings and discussion in English, with consideration of the cultural context.   CL: 2020.

name: Topics in French Culture
description: Intensive one-term study of a particular topic identified by title. Taught in English.   CL: 2020.

name: French Phonetics
description: Analysis of and practice in pronunciation and listening comprehension.   FS: 09/09/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced Oral Practice
description: Development and maintenance of speaking and listening skills at the advanced level. Offered Pass-Fail only. May be repeated.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Reading French Texts
description: Reading, discussion, and written analysis of French texts, both literary and nonliterary.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced Oral Communication
description: Current issues and events presented in French-language media. Discussion and presentations in French provide practice with advanced structures and idiomatic speech.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Composition
description: Practice in French composition; intensive review of French grammar.   FS: 9/13/2017

name: Introduction to Business French
description: Practical oral and written communication in a commercial context; introduction to business terminology and correspondence.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: The French Theatre Experience
description: Project work in the production of plays in French. Includes readings in and public performance of French theatre and related materials.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Language Study Abroad
description: Intensive language practice with special attention to oral skills. Classroom instruction by native speakers.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Service Learning in the French-Speaking World
description: Cultural and linguistic service-learning experience in a French-speaking environment.  Course may be repeated once in a different location.   CL: 2020.

name: The French Film Experience
description: An introduction to the history of the French film, with special emphasis on the aesthetic appreciation of the films in their artistic and cultural context. Films in French, with English subtitles. Taught in English. To be counted towards FREN major or minor.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Selected Topics in French & Francophone Culture
description: Intensive study of selected topics of the French-speaking world. May be repeated for credit under a different title. May not be counted for major or minor credit. Note: Taught in English. To be counted towards FREN major or minor.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Cultural History
description: French history and the arts from early times through the Napoleonic era.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced Business French
description: Commercial organizations and businesses in France. Practical business correspondence. Terminology and techniques in commercial transactions with the Certificat Pratique of the Paris Chamber of Commerce in view. Taught in French.   CL: 2020.

name: Topics in Literature
description: May be repeated for credit.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Literature and Culture Before 1800
description: Study and discussion of French works written before 1800 within their cultural and historical contexts.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Literature and Culture After 1800
description: Study and discussion of French works written after 1800 within their cultural and historical contexts.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Francophone Literatures and Cultures
description: Study and discussion of works from French-speaking societies outside France, with attention to their cultural contexts and historical contexts.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Contemporary France
description: Readings in and discussion of the culture of contemporary France.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Current Events in the France and the Francophone World
description: Development of advanced oral skills in French. Study of linguistic and cultural aspects of French language media.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Techniques of Literary Analysis
description: Texts from standard authors, with emphasis on explication de texte.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced French Stylistics
description: Practice in descriptive and narrative composition with special attention to contrastive stylistics; thme et version.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: French Phonology
description: The sound system and its functioning in the morphological system of French from the point of view of current phonological theory.   CL: 2020.

name: French Linguistics
description: The structure, morphology, and syntax of modern French.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in French
description: Poetry, prose, theatre, cinema, civilization, language, linguistics. Unique opportunities will be announced by title.  May be repeated.   FS: 9/13/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Intensive Readings in French
description: Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language reading requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only. Grades S/U for graduates and undergraduates.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Geography
description: A survey of the principles and methods of geographic inquiry. Not required for the geography major.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Physical Geography
description: Basic concepts of landform geography, climatology and meteorology, and biogeography.   FS: 06/06/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: The Digital Earth
description: Introduction to geographic data; use of digital maps and aerial/satellite images as means of Earth observation; basics of spatial data analysis; location-based Web APPs; digital map services.     FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Globalization and World Regions
description: Introduction to processes of political, economic, social, and environmental change around the world; topics include geopolitical transitions, nationalism, trade, uneven development, conflict, environmental geopolitics, and demographic change, with an emphasis on non-U.S. contexts.   FS: 02/03/2022.

name: Landform Geography
description: Hydrology, soil science, and interpretation of physical features formed by water, wind, and ice, with emphasis on environmental change.  Three hours of lecture and one two-hour laboratory per week.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Weather and Climate
description: Processes that influence weather and climate patterns on the earth.  Three lectures and one two-hour laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Peoples, Places, and Environments
description: Basic principles of human geography.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of South Carolina
description: An intensive regional analysis of South Carolina. Selected phenomena such as urbanization, industrialization, land use, the physical environment, and their interrelationships.   FS:  04/03/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of Latin America
description: Physical and human geography of Latin America.   FS: 04/03/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of North America
description: Physical and human geography of North America with emphasis on the United States.   FS: 06/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of Europe
description: Physical and human geography of Europe.   FS: 06/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of the Middle East
description: A regional geographic approach to the environmental, social, economic, and political aspects of the Middle East (Southwest Asia and north Africa) with emphasis on contemporary problems.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of Sub-Saharan Africa
description: A regional approach to the physical, social, economic, and political aspects of Sub-Saharan Africa with emphasis on contemporary problems.   FS: 04/03/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Drones for Airborne Spatial Data
description: This course is an introduction to the use of small unmanned aerial systems (UAS) in collecting/processing imagery for mapping/information analysis.  Course content includes UAS characteristics, small camera considerations, project planning and processing, and legal requirements in the United States and selected European countries.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Topics in Geography
description: Selected topics of special interest in geography. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 04/01/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Cultural Geography
description: The temporal-spatial relationship between humans and the natural environment with emphasis on the role through time of human activity in changing the face of the earth.

name: Geography and Global Geopolitics
description: Geographic perspectives on problems in international relations. Political geographic analysis of contemporary world problems.

name: Economic Geography
description: Spatial interrelation and linking of economic activities and how location affects the nature of economic systems.

name: Cities in a Changing World
description: An overview of historical and contemporary urban development and growth, with an emphasis on post-colonial and non-Western contexts.    FS: 06/02/2021.

name: Sustainable Cities
description: Overview of the relationships between urbanization and environmental processes and an exploration of pathways to greater sustainability.   FS: 04/02/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Landscapes of the United States
description: Geographic change through time in the United States, with emphasis on evolution of the American landscape. Physical environment as modified by human intervention over time within a regional framework.

name: The Geography of Disasters
description: The study of disasters, their triggering mechanisms (natural, human, technological), their spatial distributions from local to global scales, and associated human responses.

name: Cartography
description: Introduction to the theory and principles of map construction including discussions of equipment and materials, lettering and symbolization, scale and generalization, data manipulation and representation. Presentation of geographic information on maps.

name: Environment and Society
description: A geographic consideration of the interactions between environment and society.  The ways in which social, economic, and cultural processes interact across local to global scales and influence environmental practices, policies, and patterns of change will be emphasized.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Geographies of American Cities
description: Overview of the development of American cities from industrial period to the present.  Special attention given to the political, economic, social processes that shape urban space and urban ways of life.   FS: 04/02/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Interpretation of Aerial Photographs
description: Theory and use of basic photo interpretation instruments and methods. Practice in acquiring and interpreting data from aerial photography for use in the physical and social sciences.

name: Climate and Society
description: Major theories and methodologies for studying the relationship between climate and society.

name: Water as a Resource
description: Introduction to spatial and institutional aspects of water availability, demand, and quality. Water storage/conveyance strategies and facilities. Real and perceived flood, drought hazards.

name: Biogeography
description: Spatial distributions of plants and animals as they relate to historical biogeographic patterns and human impact on the biosphere.

name: Cartographic Animation
description: Introduction to theories and principles of cartographic animation.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of Wind
description: Fundamental principles of wind formation, measurement, and its impacts on the natural and human environment €“ landscape, human settlement and health, transportation, and energy.

name: Geographic Information Systems
description: Introduction to principles and methods of geographic information systems including discussion of computers, spatial data, analysis, and display. Includes discussion of applications and hands-on experience.   FS: 09/14/2022.

name: Hurricanes and Tropical Climatology
description: Atmospheric circulation, structure, and processes of tropical climates and hurricanes. Forecasting and model simulations of hurricanes. Temporal variations of tropical climate change and hurricanes.

name: America€s National Parks
description: Resource, managerial, and recreational-use components of the national park system; contemporary issues, problems, and managerial alternatives.

name: Air Pollution Climatology
description: Fundamentals, processes, and issues associated with air pollution. Emphasis is on the role of the atmosphere, how air pollution affects surface climate, and how climate and meteorology influence air quality.

name: World Tourism Geography
description: Geographic analysis of tourism in America and selected world regions; demand, supply, transportation, and cultural/environmental impact of tourism and travel.

name: Global Geography of Human Rights
description: Geopolitical, historical, cultural, and economic geographies of human rights around the world; issues of development, environment, health, inequality, violence.   FS: 12/02/2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Seminar in Geography
description: Research methods and projects; restricted to students with at least 15 hours of credit in geography.  Restricted to students with at least 15 hours of credit in geography.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics: Service Learning in Geography
description: Service learning experience in conjunction with designated Geography courses. Direct, hands-on service experience with an agency, voluntary organization, or community-based project. May be repeated, as content varies by title. Students enrolled in designated Geography courses   by Instructor permission.    FS: 03/04/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Research on a significant geography problem in the local environment. Emphasis will be on the development of relatively individualized experiences in scientific investigation.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Senior research thesis on a problem of fundamental geographic significance, supervised by faculty member; must include a written final project report.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

name: Special Topics in Geographic Research
description: Selected topics of special interest in geography. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Planning and Locational Analysis
description: Scientific approaches to locational problems in urban and regional planning, including regional growth and decline, land use control, public facility location and provision, and locational efficiency.

name: Migration and Globalization
description: A survey of the political, economic, and social causes and consequences of migration. Topics include immigration policy, border control, settlement patterns, transnationalism, multiculturalism, and integration. Selected contemporary and historical cases.   CL: 2020.

name: Political Geography
description: Concepts of space and power and their relationship to polities, elections, geopolitics, identities, law, economics, populations, and civil society.

name: Coastal Zone Management
description: Analysis of the competing demands for limited resources in the coastal zone with emphasis on the role of management in the resolution of conflicts over resource use.

name: Socionatural Coastlines in Global Perspective
description: A discussion-based seminar course that examines nature-society relations in coastal regions globally. The course will use social theory to understand how uneven development processes shaped €“ and continue shaping €“ current coastlines. We will explore key topics including coastal capitalism, delta ecologies, and climate justice via several global case studies.   FS: 12/01/2021.

name: Landscapes of South Carolina
description: An examination of the factors responsible for creating the contemporary South Carolina cultural landscape.

name: Geographical Analysis of Transportation
description: Analysis of transportation systems and the application of geographic tools to transportation planning.

name: Environmental Hazards
description: Human and environmental contributions to the generation and management of hazards originating from extreme natural events to technological failures. Contemporary public policy issues at the national and international level.

name: Quantitative Methods in Geographic Research
description: A survey of basic quantitative approaches for handling and interpreting geographically related data; univariate and bivariate procedures applicable to a variety of problems.

name: Hazards Analysis and Planning
description: Examination of the geo-spatial aspects of hazards analysis and planning with specific reference to disaster preparedness, recover, mitigation, and resilience.     FS: 04/02/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Global Food Politics
description: Political, social, and cultural landscapes of food and farming around the world; issues of agricultural production, trade, consumption, and food security.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced Cartography
description: Planning, compiling, constructing, and evaluating thematic maps. Theory and practice in scribing, separation and screening, color proofing, and map reproduction. Discussions of the process of map communication and the ways the cartographer can improve that communication.   CL: 2020.

name: Dynamic Cartography
description: Theories and principles of interactive and animated cartographic design.   CL: 2020.

name: Geography of the City
description: The influence of political boundaries, historical forces, settlement patterns, and transportation processes on urban life.

name: Synoptic Meteorology
description: Analysis of synoptic-scale circulation using weather maps, soundings, cross sections, thermodynamic diagrams, numerical models, and imagery.   CL: 2020.

name: Applied Climatology
description: Analysis of climate applications in natural and human-modified environments. Content may include water resources, solar energy, urban planning, air quality, agriculture, and tourism. Course work includes lab and field experimentation.

name: Fluvial Geomorphology
description: Introduction to landforms and processes associated with flowing water at the earth€s surface. Hydrology, sedimentology, and theories of channel formation and drainage basin evolution.

name: Water and Watersheds
description: Spatial variation of hydrology, water quality, and water-related hazards, including runoff generation, soil erosion, sedimentation, and flood hazards. Emphasizes a watershed perspective using geographic data and methods.   CL: 2020.

name: Principles of Remote Sensing
description: Introduction to remote sensing. A variety of imaging systems including black and white, color, and high altitude color infrared photographs, LANDSAT, thermal infrared, and active microwave. Use of remote sensing for studying the extra-terrestrial environment and earth weather systems.

name: LiDARgrammetric and Photogrammetric Digital Surface Mapping
description: Introduction to fundamental concepts used to map topographic and planimetric Earth surface features using digital LiDAR (LiDARgrammetric) and digital soft-copy photogrammetry (Photogrammetric).   CL: 2020.

name: Spatial Programming
description: Computer programming of spatial problems; spatial statistical analysis, interactive graphics, and computer maps.

name: WebGIS
description: Web-based Geographic Information Systems (WebGIS), including concepts and principles of WebGIS, web programming fundamentals, web-based mapping techniques, and developing WebGIS applications.    FS: 04/04/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Source Materials for Geographic Instruction
description: Introduction to selected materials available for all levels of instruction in geography. Emphasis on the substantive nature of the materials.   CL: 2020.

name: Contemporary Issues in Geography Education
description: Key concepts of geography and current approaches to teaching geography with specific attention to classroom materials, curriculum reform, cross-curricular integration, learning theory, and the use of geospatial/instructional technology.   FS: 11/06/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Satellite Mapping and the Global Positioning System
description: Technology and use of Global Positioning Systems (GPS). GPS space segment, receiver technologies, range observables, and positioning accuracy. Applications to large/medium scale mapping, remote sensing, and aerial photography.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced Geographic Information Systems
description: Theory and application of geographic information systems including discussions of automated input, storage, analysis, integration, and display of spatial data. Use of an operational geographic information system.

name: GIS-Based Modeling
description: Geographical information systems for modeling physical/human processes in space and time using raster and vector data. Cartographic modeling concepts, embedded models, and GIS-model coupling.

name: Geographic Information System (GIS) Databases and Their Use
description: Representation, construction, maintenance, and analysis of spatial data in a geographic information system (GIS) database.   CL: 2020.

name: Social Aspects of Environmental Planning and Management
description: Geographical approach to environmental problems.   CL: 2020.

name: Long-Term Environmental Change
description: Climatic changes of the past and their impact on the physical landscape, with an emphasis on the Quaternary period.   CL: 2020.

name: Human Dimensions of Global Environmental Change
description: Consequences of increasing anthropogenic changes on environmental systems including the sources of change, regional impacts, and social and policy responses.   CL: 2020.

name: International Development and the Environment
description: Intersections of international development and environmental change; study of general theoretical perspectives balanced with case studies from the Global South.   FS: 12/05/2018.

name: Geography of Public Land and Water Policy
description: Geography of public land, water, and related public trust resources (wildlife, timber, minerals, fuels, recreation, wetlands, coastal zones, wilderness); historical geography of policy; spatial aspects of current research and management.

name: Microclimatology
description: Field techniques and processes in the atmospheric boundary layer including radiation, soil heat fluxes, turbulence, momentum, latent and sensible heat fluxes, moisture, and evaporation.   CL: 2020.

name: Climatic Change and Variability
description: Observations and theories of climatic change and variability as they occur at different space and time scales. Projections of future climates. Techniques used in climatic change research and impact analysis.   CL: 2020.

name: Digital Techniques and Applications in Remote Sensing
description: Introduction to digital image processing techniques and applications. Image correction, enhancement, spatial and spectral transformation. Land use/land cover classification, and change detection.   FS: 12/03/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Globalization and Cultural Questions
description: This course examines cultural understandings of and responses to globalization, examining topics such as its history and theories, migration, economic integration and inequality, identity, social movements, and the environment.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Beach-Dune Interactions
description: Influence of wind on coastal systems, with emphasis on nearshore currents, sediment transport and bedforms, aeolian transport, and dunes.   Minimum Junior standing required.   CL: 2020.

name: Internship in Geography
description: Internship in government agencies, private-sector businesses, and non-profit organizations under the joint supervision of sponsor and departmental. A maximum of three credits may be applied to undergraduate Geography major or to Geography master's degree. May be repeated to a maximum of six credits.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: History of Geographic Thought
description: A survey of the development of geographic philosophy and an analysis of geographic methodology.

name: Introduction to the Earth
description: Origin and nature of the earth with emphasis on internal processes and phenomena such as earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building; surface processes, including landform evolution.  Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Fossils and the Evolution of Life on Earth
description: Basic overview of fossils, including dinosaurs, and their importance for understanding earth history and the evolution of life.  Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week.   CL: 2020.

name: Environment of the Earth
description: Analysis of basic energy cycles of the earth. Interaction of human activity with earth processes to affect the environment.  Three lectures and three laboratory hours each week. Field trips required.   FS: 06/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Cultural Geology
description: The growth of geological concepts, scientific and non-scientific. The impact of geological factors on human affairs. The role of time and evolution (biological and physical). Restricted to non-science majors.   FS: 11/04/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: The Water Planet
description: Introduction to the origin of water and water properties, water in the universe, water in the solar system, water on Earth and its geological history.   FS: 02/01/2023.

name: Observing the Earth
description: An introduction to study of the earth through observation of ancient and modern earth systems in a field setting.  Field trips required.   CL: 2020.

name: Earth Resources
description: Mineral, energy, and water resources with emphasis on geological processes governing their distribution. Intended for non-science majors.  Three lecture hours each week with occasional field trips.   CL: 2020.

name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S.
description: Coastal zones of South Carolina and neighboring states, including geologic history, geomorphology, stratigraphy, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and effects of man. Not available for geological science or marine science major credit. Three lecture hours each week plus optional field trips.   FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Coastal Environments of the Southeastern U.S. (Laboratory)
description: Exercises examining coastal ecology, geomorphology, hydrogeology, shoreline processes, environmental issues, and human impact. Not available for marine science major credit. Two laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips required.    Prerequiste or Corequisite: D or better in GEOL 215 or MSCI 215.   FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Geology of the National Parks
description: Examination of the geologic setting and scientific significance of selected National Parks.  Three lecture hours.   CL: 2020.

name: Rocks and Minerals
description: Chemical and physical processes of mineral formation in earth systems including an overview of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rock-forming processes. Includes laboratory. Field trips required.   FS: 06/03/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Earth Systems through Time
description: Survey of earth history, the evolution of continents and oceans, the history of life, and geological dating methods.  Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips. Taught alternate years.   CL: 2020.

name: Surface and Near Surface Processes
description: Overview of groundwater, surface water hydrology, sediment transport, river systems, and coastal processes.  Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.   CL: 2020.

name: Field Studies in Geology
description: Directed field studies of extraordinary geological locations in North America.  Requires a seven- to nine-day field trip during spring break.   CL: 2020.

name: Stratigraphy and Sedimentary Basins
description: Overview of sedimentary basins, sediment transport, sedimentation, depositional environments, stratigraphy, seismic stratigraphy, eustacy, and sedimentary petrology.   Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.   FS: 03/07/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Processes of Global Environmental Change
description: The science of global change, its relation to the hydrosphere, atmosphere, lithosphere, and biosphere. Global system science, biogeochemical cycles, paleoclimatology, glaciation, and eustacy.   FS: 12/4/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Igneous and Metamorphic Processes
description: Origin and significance of igneous and metamorphic rocks, and relation to tectonic processes.  Mineralogy, geochemistry, volcanism, plate tectonics, isostasy, heat flow.   Includes laboratory and recitation.  Required field trips.    FS: 06/03/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Structural Geology and Tectonics
description: Geologic structures and deformation of Earth materials.  Stress and strain, deformation mechanisms, P-T-t paths, geologic maps, and structural regimes in plate tectonics.    Includes laboratory and recitation. Required field trips.   FS: 06/03/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: A View of the River
description: Introduction to terrestrial and tidal river morphology and processes, with case studies of South Carolina.  Field trips required.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of regional and fundamental significance, supervised by a faculty member of the student€s choice. Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking and lucid scientific report writing.   CL: 2020.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Student research on problems of regional and fundamental significance, supervised by a faculty member of the student€s choice. Emphasis is on the development of critical thinking and lucid scientific report writing.   CL: 2020.

name: Field Geology
description: Geological field techniques including the use of field instruments and the preparation of geologic maps. Written and oral reports required.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Principles of Geomorphology
description: The process of earth denudation with emphasis on chemistry of weathering, stream and erosion hydraulics, quantitative analysis of land form evolution.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Principles of Coastal Geomorphology
description: Geological and physical controls on the morphology, development, and stability of coastlines. Analysis of waves and erosional processes, and coastal zone morphodynamics. Several required field trips.   CL: 2020.

name: Regional Stratigraphy and Biostratigraphy of North America
description: Sedimentologic, biostratigraphic, and tectonic history of North America, approached from paleogeographic considerations with emphasis on the Atlantic Coastal Plain and Continental Margin.  Three hours lecture and three hours recitation per week. Required field trips.   CL: 2020.

name: Climate Geoengineering
description: This course will discuss the urgent need for deploying solar radiation and carbon dioxide removal approaches at scale, including potential benefits and risks of these options.  It will also discuss regulatory and governance considerations at both the national and international level and strategizes to incentivize large-scale adoption of these approaches.   FS: 12/07/2022.

name: Advanced Paleontology
description: Systematic, ecologic, biogeographic, and evolutionary aspects of paleontology; lectures, practical exercises, field trips.   FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Marine Micropaleontology
description: Marine microfossils; distribution, ecology, paleoecology, and biostratigraphy; use of microfossils in marine sediments to study oceanographic history.   Three lectures and two laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Sedimentology
description: Modern concepts of sediment composition, sedimentary facies, depositional environments, and stratigraphy.  Includes laboratory.   CL: 2020.

name: Surface to Subsurface Stratigraphy
description: Surface to subsurface stratigraphic interpretation and techniques; litho- and biostratigraphy; geophysical log interpretation and subsurface presentation.   CL: 2020.

name: Isotope Geology and Geochronology
description: Dating techniques for Pleistocene deposits, sediments, archaeological materials, igneous and metamorphic rocks.

name: Introduction to Geochemistry
description: Investigation of low temperature chemical reactions controlling the geochemistry of the earth€s surface. Emphasis on CO2, carbonates, oxidation-reduction, thermodynamics, isotopes, biogeochemistry.   CL: 2020.

name: Environmental Radioisotope Geochemistry
description: Introduction to radioactivity and the use of radionuclides to study environmental processes, including age-dating and biogeochemical cycling in aquatic systems.   FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Igneous Petrology
description: Petrography and petrogenesis of igneous rocks; evolution of contrasting petrotectonic terranes.  Three lectures and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Metamorphic Petrology
description: Petrography and petrogenesis of metamorphic rocks in orogenic belts. Three lectures and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Plate Tectonics
description: Geological and geophysical evidence for plate tectonics, detailed development of the plate tectonics model, and present areas of research, including measurements of plate motion using satellite geodesy.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 20200.

name: Field Methods in Geophysics
description: Application of two or more geophysical field methods to a current geological problem. Independent study contract required.

name: Earth Science for Teachers I
description: Origin, internal structure and internal processes of the earth, including plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building. Required field trips, two lectures, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

name: Earth Science for Teachers II
description: Surface processes acting on the earth; introduction to weather and climate, weathering, erosion, and sedimentary processes; land form evolution; ocean currents and tides, near-shore geologic processes. Required field trips, two lecture, and three lab hours per week. Cannot be used in MS or PhD programs in geology.

name: Methods in Geoscience Education Research
description: Introduction to methods used in discipline-based education research and their application to research questions in the geosciences.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Geological Oceanography
description: A comprehensive study of the origin and development of the major structural features of the ocean basins and the continental margins. Discussion of the techniques used in obtaining geologic data and the interpretation of sedimentary processes, vulcanism, and the stratigraphy of the ocean basins.   CL:  2020.

name: Marine Geophysics
description: Introduction to the nature and structure of the ocean floor as revealed by geophysical techniques.  Two hours lecture and three hours laboratory.   CL: 2020.

name: Environmental Geophysics
description: Practical geophysical techniques for exploring the shallow subsurface. Seismic, resistivity, well log, gravity, magnetic method. Includes lectures and field exercises to collect and analyze data.   FS: 09/09/15.   CL: 2020.

name: Sedimentary Simulations and Sequence Stratigraphy
description: Problems of sequence stratigraphy resolved with graphic computer simulations. Sedimentary fill of basins by carbonates and/or clastics tracked as a function of rate of sediment accumulation, tectonic behavior, and sea level. Includes laboratory.   CL: 2020.

name: Marine Sediments
description: Marine sedimentary environments; physical/biological factors which control the formation and distribution of modern marine sediments.   CL: 2020.

name: Applied Seismology
description: Theory of seismic wave propagation. Seismic reflection data acquisition, processing, and interpretation.   CL: 2020.

name: Elementary Seismology
description: Basic elements of seismology. Mathematical development of seismic wave equations; measurement, description, and interpretation of seismic data.   CL: 2020.

name: Seismic Reflection Interpretation
description: The interpretation of geologic structure using seismic sections. Recognition of apparent structure caused by velocity anomalies, multiples, and complex reflector geometry. Application to hydrocarbon exploration.

name: Coastal Processes
description: Physical and geological processes controlling the formation and evolution of beach, barrier, and nearshore environments, including discussion of coastal management issues.   FS: 11/06/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Earth Resource Management
description: An approach to problems of resource management by lecture and seminar using case studies in mineral, energy, hydrogeological, and environmental science.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Environmental Field Geology
description: An introduction to field methods in sedimentology, structural geology, hydrogeology and geophysics with special reference to geological hazards and environmental problems.

name: Long-Term Environmental Change
description: Climatic changes of the past and their impact on the physical landscape, with an emphasis on the Quaternary period.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Micrometeorology
description: Small-scale processes in the atmospheric boundary layers, including energy budget, radiation, soil heat transfer, humidity, viscous flows, turbulence, momentum and heat exchanges, evaporation, and marine atmospheric boundary layer.    FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Environmental Hydrogeology
description: Environmental considerations of the hydrologic cycle, occurrence and movement of ground water, aquifer analysis, and water well emplacement and construction. Water quality, pollution parameters, and the geochemistry of selected natural systems. The effects of environmental problems, waste disposal, and urban development upon the aqueous geochemical regime.   CL: 2020.

name: Soil Hydrology
description: Saturated and unsaturated water flow through soils, pore pressure development, runoff generation, and watershed response to rainfall.  Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Numerical Modeling for Earth Science Applications
description: Finite difference and finite element methods for solving the diffusion equation and advection-dispersion equation, with applications in hydrogeology, geophysics, geology, and marine science.   CL: 2020.

name: Air-Sea Interaction
description: The physical mechanism responsible for interaction between the ocean and the atmosphere and the influence of air-sea interaction on atmospheric and oceanic dynamics and thermodynamics on a wide variety of spatial/temporal scales.   CL: 2020.

name: Satellite Oceanography
description: This course provides knowledge of various techniques used in satellite remote sensing of the oceans. Key skills will be developed in satellite data processing, image analysis, and hands-on research.   CL: 2020.

name: Estuarine Oceanography
description: Estuarine kinematics and dynamics; classification of estuaries; estuarine circulation and mixing.  Scheduled field trips are required.   FS: 04/01/2015.   CL: 2020.

name: Marine Hydrodynamics
description: Basic principles of fluid statics and dynamics. Conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; viscosity, vorticity, and boundary layers with examples from the marine environment. Applications to and analysis of ocean currents and waves.     FS: 03/03/2021.

name: Geology and Geochemistry of Salt Marshes
description: Geological and geochemical processes in salt marshes. Methods of geological research in marshes including instrumental techniques, sampling design, and data analysis. Two lectures per week plus four weekends of project oriented fieldwork and/or equivalent lab work. Scheduled field trips are required.

name: Senior Seminar in Geology and Geophysics
description: Advanced research topics in geology and geophysics; critical reading of literature, technical presentations, and written reports.  Senior standing.   CL: 2020.

name: Electron Microscopy and Microanalysis
description: SEM, ESEM, TEM, and EMPA, WDS quantitative analysis, EDS semi-quantitative analysis, EBSD, methods of sample preparation, and applications in varieties of disciplines.  Two lecture and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Senior capstone experience, research on a problem on fundamental significance, supervised by faculty member; must include field study component, written final project report, and oral presentation at departmental seminar.    CL: 2020.

name: Beginning German I
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.  Restricted to those who have never studied German or who have placed by examination into GERM 109. Credit may be received only for one of the following GERM 109; GERM110; GERM 111; GERM 121.   CL: 2020.

name: Beginning German II
description: Introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills.  Credit may be received only for one of the following: GERM 109; GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.   CL: 2020.

name: Intensive Beginning German
description: Intensive introduction to grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Admission only to highly motivated beginning students who obtain permission of the department. Credit may be received only for one of the following: GERM 109 and GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.   CL: 2020.

name: Elementary German
description: Grammar and vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes prior experience in German. Admission only by proficiency examination. Credit may be received for only one of the following: GERM 109; GERM 110; GERM 111; GERM 121.   CL: 2020.

name: Basic Proficiency in German
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills.   CL: 2020.

name: Intermediate German
description: Further development of listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills; discussion of selected literary texts, and current issues; intensive review of basic grammar structures.   CL: 2020.

name: Intermediate German
description: Reading strategies, a review, and expansion of grammar structures, supplemented with materials concerning current issues.   CL: 2020.

name: The Idea of Nature in Germany
description: The idea of nature in Germany from the 18th century to today. Focus on scientific, philosophical, social and political entanglements that prompt radical shifts in how German thinkers view nature.   FS: 12/03/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Knights and Ladies
description: Survey of medieval romances and love lyrics of Germany.  History and culture of the High Middle Ages in Germany, especially courtly society.  The function of chivalry and courtly literature in society.   FS: 06/04/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: German Culture and Civilization
description: Survey of German cultural history from the Middle Ages to the present.  Taught in English.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Viking Mythology
description: Survey of Germanic mythological and heroic texts of the Viking Age.  History and culture of Germanic tribes, especially the Vikings. The function of myth in society.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Green Technology in Germany
description: Examination of roots and culture of environmentalism and related technological innovation in Germany. Comparison of green practices around the world to practices within Europe and U.S.   FS: 12/04/2013.    CL: 2020.

name: German Conversation
description: Continued practice in the four skills with focus on a selected aspect of German culture and society.   CL: 2020.

name: German Conversation and Composition
description: Continued practice in the four skills with emphasis on developing writing skills and with focus on a specific aspect of German culture.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced German for Business and Other Professions I
description: Development of advanced language and cultural skills necessary for functioning in the professional world of German-speaking countries.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: German Kabarett Production
description: Literary-historical analysis and discussion of texts from German Kabarett, including comedic skits, political and social satire, parody, humorous poetry. Semester ends with a public performance in German.   CL: 2020.

name: Study of German Abroad
description: Intensive language practice and cultural studies. May be repeated for credit by permission.   CL: 2020.

name: Readings in German Literature
description: An introduction to the literary genres illustrated by masterpieces in German poetry, drama, and prose.   CL: 2020.

name: Selected Topics
description: Taught in English. Intensive study of cultural and/or literary movements in German-speaking countries. Course content varies by title.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Practicum in Teaching German to Young Children
description: Introduction to principles of foreign language instruction and field experience planning instruction and teaching German to children in local elementary schools.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced German Grammar
description: Emphasis on advanced grammar structures, with continued development of all four skills (reading, writing, listening, speaking).   FS: 12/06/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced German Conversation
description: Advanced practice in correct spoken idiomatic German with special focus on issues of the 20th century and contemporary culture.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: Advanced German for Business and Other Professions II
description: Development of advanced language and cultural skills necessary for functioning in the professional world of German-speaking countries. Preparation for standardized exams.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Medieval German Literature and Culture
description: Survey of German literature and culture from the beginnings to 1350, including Germanic mythology and heroic poetry, conversion to Christianity, courtly romance and love lyric, mystical writings, art and architecture.   FS: 12/03/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: The German Enlightenment and its Countercurrents
description: German literature and culture of the 18th century with emphasis on the period between 1750 and Weimar Classicism. May include major works by Lessing, Goethe, and Schiller.   FS: 12/03/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: German Literature and Culture from 1800-1871
description: German literary, cultural, and intellectual developments from Unification to the end of WWII, including Naturalism, Expressionism, the Weimar Republic, the Third Reich, and the exile period.   FS: 12/04/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: German Literature from 1890-1945
description: German literary, cultural, and intellectual developments from 1890 to 1945, including Expressionism, Weimar Republic, the Third Reich, and exile period.   CL: 2020.

name: Post-War and Contemporary German Literature
description: German literary, cultural and political developments from Post-War destruction and reconstruction, through the Cold War period of division, with examination of the reunification process.   CL: 2020.

name: Survey of German Culture
description: Historical survey of the German contribution to the intellectual and cultural life of Europe. Texts and films in German.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to German Linguistics
description: Structural and descriptive linguistics applied to the German language.   FS: 12/05/2018.

name: History of the German Language
description: Development of German in the Germanic, Old High German, Middle High German, and New High German periods. Phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and the relationship between dialects and the standard language.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to the Germanic Languages
description: Introduction to historical Germanic linguistics including a survey of the Old Germanic languages (Old English, Old Frisian, Old Saxon, Old High German, Old Norse, Gothic); comparative phonology, morphology, and syntax, typology of modern Germanic languages and dialects; and common Germanic in its Indo-European context.   CL: 2020.

name: German Sociolinguistics
description: Introduction to the study of variation in Modern German. Traditional German dialectology and dialect geography, language and society, multilingualism in the German-speaking countries, German in contact with other languages.   CL: 2020.

name: Topics in German Film
description: Examination of recurring themes and issues or of significant periods and influential styles in German film. Course content varies and individual topics will be announced with course title.   CL: 2020.

name: Intensive Readings in German
description: Intensive reading for non-majors. Graduate students fulfill their foreign-language requirement with successful completion of the course. Undergraduates may take the course as an elective only by permission of instructor. Grades S/U for graduates and undergraduates.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Global Studies Through Literature
description: Given that literature represents real policies and practices in the contemporary world and our ethical responsibility as global citizens, the course will focus on literature from different periods, nations, and regions across the world in order to better understand the way human experiences and different cultures relate. All literature will be read and taught in English.   FS: 04/03/2019.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to International Development
description: Critical, historical, and theoretical introduction to modern development practice. Includes extended discussions of contemporary best practices in the field.   FS: 11/07/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Global Media Industries
description: Provides the foundation for the study of globalized film and media industries.   FS: 11/1/2017.   CL: 2020.

name: History of Capitalism 1: Ancient and Medieval World
description: History of "capitalist" economic behavior and culture in various premodern societies: the Ancient Middle East, Classical Greece, the Roman Empire, early Islamic society, medieval Christian and Islamic states, the Mongol period and the era of global expansionism; evaluation of competing theories about premodern economic life and the meaning of "capitalism"   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: History of Capitalism From the Industrial Revolution to the Global Economy
description: A history of capitalism and its evolving definitions in Europe from the Middle Ages to the 20th Century, including its role in agriculture, mechanical industry, international trade, and colonialism and domination.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

name: Topics in Global Studies
description: Selected topics in Global Studies.  May be repeated with a change in topic. May be taken three times for credit.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

name: Global Studies Internship
description: Academic counterpart to a professional work experience in which global or international affairs play a central role. Provides an introduction to foreign affairs and intercultural interactions in a working environment. Introduction to career possibilities for a student trained in global studies.   Global Studies major with 3.0 or better GPA and completion of at least 45 credits.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

name: Elementary Ancient Greek I
description: Basic grammar and vocabulary necessary for reading Classical and Koine Greek. Assumes no prior experience in the language.   FS:09/08/2021.

name: Elementary Ancient Greek II
description: Additional grammar and vocabulary necessary for reading Classical and Koine Greek.   FS: 09/08/2021.

name: The Greek New Testament
description: Readings in the Gospels and Epistles.   FS: 10/02/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: Plato
description: The life of Socrates based on the reading of Plato€s Apology and Crito in Greek. Supplementary reading in English from Xenophon€s Memorabilia and Aristophanes€ Clouds.   CL: 2020.

name: Homer
description: Readings from the Iliad and the Odyssey in Greek. Discussion of the language, background, and composition of the poems.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Herodotus
description: Readings from the Histories.   CL: 2020.

name: Thucydides
description: Readings from the History of the Peloponnesian War.

name: Sophocles
description: Selected plays.

name: Euripides
description: Selected plays.

name: Hesiod and the Homeric Hymns
description: Readings from the Works and Days, the Theogony, and the Homeric Hymns.

name: Greek Seminar
description: Authors and topics not covered in other Greek language courses, chosen to meet the needs of individual students. May be repeated with the approval of the department.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Independent Study
description: Special projects for independent study and research.

name: Intensive Grammar Review of Ancient Attic Greek
description: Intensive review for nonmajors designed to prepare them for GREK 615.

name: Intensive Readings in Ancient Attic Greek
description: Intensive reading for nonmajors. A review of grammar and syntax with reading of passages from Plato€s Apology. Primarily for graduate students to fulfill the foreign-language reading requirement.    CL: 2020.

name: Elementary Hebrew
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language. Offered only in fall.

name: Basic Proficiency in Hebrew
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Offered only in spring.   CL: 2020.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Review of the basic principles of grammar, with emphasis on reading, oral skills, and writing.

name: Intermediate Hebrew
description: Review of the basic principles of grammar, with emphasis on reading, oral skills, and writing.

name: Conversation and Composition
description: Practical training in the spoken and written language.   CL: 2020.

name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study in selected and cultural topics related to Judaism. May be repeated for credit under different titles. Taught in English.   CL: 2020.

name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

name: Genetic Counseling: Career for the Future
description: Introduction to the genetic counseling profession including professional literature and online resources.   Preparation for graduation education in genetic counseling.   FS: 11/05/2014.   CL: 2020.

name: European Civilization from Ancient Times to the Mid-17th Century
description: The rise and development of European civilization from its Mediterranean origins through the Renaissance and Reformation.   CL: 2020.

name: European Civilization from the Mid-17th Century
description: European development and expansion from the mid-17th century to the present.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to South Asian History
description: Political, cultural, and economic forces that have conditioned the development of institutions and ideas in South Asia.   FS: 02/03/2016.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to the Civilization of the Islamic Middle East
description: An analysis which treats the major cultural elements of traditional Islamic civilization and then concentrates upon the reactions of the Arabs, Turks, and Iranians to the problems of adjusting to the modern world.   FS: 11/04/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to East Asian Civilization
description: The evolution of social, political, and cultural patterns in East Asia, with emphasis on the development of philosophical, religious, and political institutions and their relationship to literary and artistic forms in China and Japan.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to African History
description: An examination of several traditional sub-Saharan African societies and of their political and economic transformation in the modern, colonial, and post-independence periods.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Ancient Near Eastern Civilization
description: The political, social, religious, economic, military, and intellectual development of Ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia, and adjoining areas from the origins of civilization until the seventh century A.D.

name: Science and Technology in World History
description: The development of science and technology and their roles in world civilizations from antiquity to the present.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

name: Introduction to Latin American Civilization
description: A discussion of the political, cultural, and economic forces which have conditioned the development of institutions and ideas in Spanish and Portuguese America.   FS: 09/09/2020.   CL: 2020.

name: Conquest, Colonization, and Captivity: A Cultural History of the Americas from 1441 to 1888
description: Comparative examination of conquest, colonization, and human captivity in the history, cultural values, and social ethics of European, African, and Indigenous civilizations in the Americas, 1441-1888.   FS: 12/02/2020.

name: United States History to 1865
description: A general survey of the United States from the era of discovery to 1865, emphasizing major political, economic, social, and intellectual developments.    FS: 06/02/2021.

name: United States History since 1865
description: A general survey of the United States from 1865 to the present, emphasizing major political, economic, social, and intellectual developments. Honors sections are available for students in the honors program.    CL: 2020.

name: American Founding Documents
description: Introduction to Declaration of independence, Constitution, Federalist Papers, Bill of Rights, landmark Supreme Court cases and constitutional amendments; exploration of these texts€ historical context and debates about their meaning.   FS: 03/03/2021.

name: History of the American West
description: The history and development of an American region, €the West,€? through the narratives of its diverse people and the effects of its complex geography.

name: The Practice of Public History
description: Introduction to the field of public history. Explores the challenges of portraying history in museums, parks, and other public history venues.   CL: 2020.

name: History of the Devil
description: A survey of the beliefs and practices associated with the demonic and the Devil from c 500 B.C.E. to the 20th century.   FS: 12/04/2013.   CL: 2020.

name: History of Crime and Punishment
description: An exploration of the evolution of global practices related to enforcing conformity with societal norms. Examines legal codes, philosophies, and technological devices associated with crime and punishment throughout history.   FS: 02/01/2023.

name: Introduction to the History Major:  The Historian€s Craft
description: The nature of historical evidence, the formulation of historical questions, the process of historical research, and the construction of historical arguments using primary sources and secondary materials.   FS: 11/02/2022.

name: The Ancient Near East to 323 B.C.
description: The formation of ancient Near Eastern cultures, the ultimate synthesis of these cultures and the resulting establishment of the Near East as an historical entity.

name: Greek History and Civilization to 146 B.C.
description: The origins and development of Greek civilization in its political, economic, social, and cultural aspects with special attention being given to the early and late classical periods and the Hellenistic Age.

name: Roman Republic and Early Empire
description: The origins of Rome and shaping of its republican government, the spread of Roman rule in Italy and across the Mediterranean, the establishment of the principate and formation of one diverse imperial society and culture.

name: Late Antiquity: Imperial Rome to Islam
description: Political, social and religious transformation of the Mediterranean world, 2nd to the 8th century., including the rise of Christianity, the decline of Roman power, and the rise of Islam.   CL: 2020.

name: Greece and Rome in Film and Popular Culture
description: Representations of antiquity in cinema, television, and other contemporary media, with emphasis on Hollywood€s reception of Greek and Roman history.   CL: 2020.

name: Medieval Europe, ca. 300-1492
description: Topics include the formation of monarchies, the rise of Christianity, learning and universities, knighthood and social orders, and heresy and crusades.

name: Family and Society in Europe, c. 1200-1700
description: Explores the concerns and importance of families in pre-modern Europe. Topics include household furnishings and management, social classes, gender roles, family law, marriages, business, children, feuds, and sexuality.

name: Magic and Witchcraft in Europe, c. 1200-1700
